Ahhh, politics!  People will always distrust the "the code passes all my
tests therefore it's clean" line because they won't trust me to write
rigourous tests to find fault with my code.   And of course they're right:
not because I'm untrustworthy, merely sometimes overconfident about my code.
That's why we need QA bods to test our code.

In your situation maybe you could adapt the XP Pair-programming technique so
that you have a developer and a QA-er writing test suites together.  The QA
gains visibility of the tests, the developer has an objective set of tests
that they have to get green.  

Although I don't hold out much hope: I've tried to interest people here in
"Pair programming" and you would have thought I proposing something dirty -
in fact I would probably have got less of an adverse reaction if I *had*
proposed something dirty ;P  

Still, it might be worth your while to try.  

I've though some more about your problem and logging test failures into
Bugzilla (or whatever) is a non-starter.  Consider: new bug logged every
time you run the same test and it fails; you have to associate a test with a
bug number; once a test passes JUnit has to search the database and update
the bug report.

If you want something that's more generally usable you might want to
consider something like Silvermark's TestMentor which comes with lots of
graphical goodies and reports :) but isn't free :(

rgds, APC

We will have nightly builds and they will run the tests and I suppose

Forgive me, but isn't this rather contrary to the spirit of JUnit and
its
TestInfected/XP approach?  Kent says we're supposed to cycle through the
testing and coding stages a few times until our code has no bugs.  So
what
is there to track?  same goes for integration: providing we're
developing in
small enough chunks, of course.

Or look at it another way: our failed tests are their own bug
trackingdevice.

Automatically populating a bug track database from failed tests would
only
make sense when the people running the tests aren't the same people who
are
developing the code, for instance users in UAT or a "black box" testing
cell.  I don't think JUnit is sufficiently abstract for the former but I
can
see that the latter could be writing their own JUnit suites (if they
know
Java).  In which case your question is simply a variant on the "How do I
log
output from JUnit?" question, only instead of writing to a logfile you
want
to insert the results into an error tracking database.  How difficult
that
is depends on the database in question: if it's something proprietary
like
Merant Tracker I imagine there'll be a few more problems than if (like
us)
you're using a homebrew system based on tables sitting in your
development
Oracle DB.  The Bugzilla FAQ does say we write to the database using the
Mozilla XML API so it would be possible to do, but I think you'll be
lucky
to find anyone who's actually done it :P  

rgds, APC
